subdebateinfo.title: Jones, Mr Alan: Appointment to Australian Sports Commission

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Minchin, the Minister representing the Minister for Sport and Tourism. Minister, is it a fact that the Department of Industry, Science and Resources dispatched the wrong paperwork to Mr Alan Jones regarding his appointment to the board of the Australian Sports Commission? Is it a fact that this is the only reason Mr Jones was appointed to deputy chair rather than as just another member of the board? Is it a fact that both the Prime Minister's office and the minister for sport had previously decided that Alan Jones was too politically risky for the position of deputy chair because of his right-wing leanings and his bias towards the Liberal Party? Can the minister inform the Senate whether this is in fact the same Alan Jones who was described by the former Victorian Liberal powerbroker Michael Kroger as `very influential in the Liberal's 1998 election victory'?

—I thank Senator Lundy for her question. It is true indeed that the government has appointed Mr Alan Jones as deputy chairperson of the Australian Sports Commission. I commend and congratulate Mr Jones on his appointment. Mr Jones is an outstanding Australian who has served this nation well in many respects. He has made an enormous contribution to sport. He is widely regarded as the most successful Australian rugby union coach ever. He will bring a lot to the board. He brings great skills and experience. The Sports Commission is the better for his appointment. I am sure he will serve that commission and the nation well.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you confirm that a bureaucrat in the department has been severely reprimanded for this mistake and has further action has been taken? Is it usual practice for a person mistakenly offered a significant government sinecure to be appointed to the post regardless, simply to avoid the embarrassment of having to rectify the stuff-up?
—Madam President, I think there could be a better choice of language to meet the high standards we would expect of senators on the other side.
—Senator Lundy, were you planning to rephrase the last part of your question?
—I am happy to exchange the word `stuff-up' for the word `mistake', Madam President.
—I am not aware of any bureaucrats having been reprimanded over this matter.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Will the minister outline the coalition's achievements in health policy, in particular the practical steps it has taken to support Australia's public hospital system?

—With pleasure, because the government's record in health stands in stark contrast to the mess we inherited after 13 years of Labor government. Just recall for one moment the Labor legacy. A hundred thousand people were on waiting lists for public hospitals. The number of people with private health insurance had plummeted from 70 per cent to 35 per cent. The cost of premiums for private health insurance had skyrocketed by 40 per cent between 1986 and 1988 alone. Twenty thousand public hospital beds were closed. Public hospitals were overflowing with people who had the capacity to pay for private cover but refused to do so, such as the former Labor Prime Minister, Mr Keating. Low income earners were dropping out of private health insurance, which we all know. There was a crisis in rural health and Medicare costs were skyrocketing—in fact, they were out of control.

answer.para: As I said, in contrast we have taken steps to address the problems of Australia's health system. We believe that all Australians should have access to high quality health care with both strong and viable public and private systems working together. We have taken practical steps to support public hospitals. This year we signed a new agreement with the states that will increase public hospital funding in real terms by 19.2 per cent over five years.

We are providing $31.3 billion in funding for public hospitals over the next five years—$31.3 billion, more than any other government in Australia's history. We are spending $120 million to reduce waiting lists in public hospitals. We are spending an extra $750 million for funding for veterans being treated in public hospitals. We have provided an additional $260 million for rural health services, such as rural GP retention grants to help rural communities keep their doctors, and 30 new regional health services centres.

We stand for a strong public system and an equally strong private system. The Labor Party, as we know, for base ideological reasons opposes the private sector and, by doing that, undermines the public sector which they profess concern about. Under our plans, the private health system will contribute over $400 million a year to the public health system. It is time that the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats listened to the majority of Australians who want more affordable private health care.

This government is proud of its achievements in the health area. For example, we have introduced the Immunise Australia program to promote vaccination as a simple vital preventative measure. Just recall: in 1996, Australia's full immunisation rate for children was only 53 per cent and now 94 per cent of children have been immunised for prevention of measles; new preventative strategies for the 650,000 Australians with diabetes; the largest and toughest anti-smoking campaign in Australia's history; the establishment of the Mental Health Council, the first national body; extra assistance for people with mental illness; a $10 million package for carers of people with dementia; 31 new Aboriginal health centres to address poor health of indigenous Australians; and the Get Tough on Drugs strategy. This is a proud record. What we now want to do is to go forward to ensure that Australians who wish to take out private health insurance can afford that also.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the minister's attention been drawn to the following statement: `As fast as we hurled money at the hospitals, there was a further abandonment of private health cover and a further rise in demand on the public system'? Who made this statement? Will the minister further outline any other government achievements in health policy?

—That is right. Who was so wise as to say, `As fast as we hurled money at the hospitals, there was a further abandonment of private health cover and a further rise in demand on the public system'? Of course, it was Bob Carr, the New South Wales Labor Premier. He recognised that to put money into the public sector alone will not solve the problems of health care. He reinforced, in fact, what Labor's current spokesman, Jenny Macklin, said, which I stated yesterday. She recognised also, when she was not in her current office, that to simply put money into the public health system does not solve the problem because it undermines the viability of the private health system to meet its share of the burden. If you listen to even Labor's spokesman outside of the atmosphere of the current debate, outside of the short-term point scoring which they are engaging in at the moment, it demonstrates that they recognise that for a healthy public system in Australia you need a healthy private system. And, therefore, you need to make it affordable for people to join and stay in the system. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Local Government

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Macdonald. Does the minister recall telling the Senate on 26 November this year, `Local government is very keen on the GST and the tax reform agenda of this government'? Is the minister aware that the Local Government Association of Queensland, his home state, has said that Queensland councils have been given a `raw deal' under the tax package and that, `We are bitterly disappointed that the federal government has turned its back on local government'? Is the minister aware that the Local Government Association of Queensland has launched Operation Rethink, aimed specifically at the coalition, to change elements of the tax package that are `detrimental to local government'? Will the minister now apologise for misleading the Senate?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —If there is any misleading of the Senate, it is in that particular question. The Local Government Association of Queensland is a fine organisation, and one with which I am very familiar, and have been for some time. I have not just blown in and had one meeting with them like you have, Senator, just the other day. You are feeling a bit excited about that. I think I could class Councillor Tom Pyne—the president of the Local Government Association of Queensland and the Mayor of Cairns, a fine city—as a good friend of mine. He is, however, a life member of the Labor Party. I have got to say that, in spite of Councillor Pyne being a great fellow and a great Queenslander, he understands which side his bread is buttered on. Most of the local governments in Queensland—and I attended a meeting of the North Queensland Local Government Association not long after I was appointed—understand the system once it is explained to them. Once you cut away the Labor lies on the GST and once they understand it, they understand that the GST will not impact on local councils.
—No, they don't.
—If they do not, Senator, it is because you tell them lies, you misrepresent it to them.
—Senator, I ask you to withdraw that and, in addition, to direct your remarks to the chair and not across the chamber.

—Thank you, Madam President. I will withdraw. But one of the problems with local government is that many Labor senators and members of parliament have mischievously given misinformation to everybody, including local councils. Once they know the situation, once local councils understand it, they embrace it. They think it is a great system because they will obtain $70 million in direct savings from the indirect application of the wholesale sales tax.

answer.para: The Local Government Association of Queensland itself said that local councils in Queensland would save up to $18 million in reduced costs on fuel. They have introduced this campaign—what is it called?—Operation Rethink. That is about the financial assistance grants going from the Commonwealth to local government. They understand—as do the New South Wales Local Government Association whom I met with last week while you were up in Queensland—that, for the first time ever, funding from the Commonwealth to local government will be guaranteed. That does not apply at the moment. A federal government can give money to local governments—and does—but they do not have to. Under our tax reform system, for the first time ever funding will be guaranteed to local government.

talk.start.para: —How?

—The senator who asked the question has absolutely no idea of how the GST system works, how tax reform works and what our proposals are for federal, state and local government relations. This is how it works, Senator, and pay attention: all the GST money goes not to the Commonwealth but to the states. The states are pushing themselves aside to sign up on the bottom line to get that money, because they see it as a growth tax. We will only give the money to the states on the condition that they guarantee existing payments to local government. When I say `guarantee existing payments', I mean existing general purpose grants and existing untied road funding. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer and I hope that, in answer to the supplementary, he can describe what precise mechanism will be used in terms of this guarantee. I would remind the minister that at the meeting I attended there were many people who were also members of the Liberal Party and the National Party and who agreed with great concern in regard to this.
—Ask your question, Senator. You should not direct your remarks straight across the chamber.

—Thank you, Madam President. Is the minister aware of the motion carried by the 1998 National General Assembly of Local Government, representing 700 councils across Australia, that rejected any proposals to transfer responsibility for local government funding to the states and territories? Will the minister admit that local government not only in Queensland but also all around Australia is utterly opposed to the handing over of funding to the states?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —First of all I would like Senator Mackay to name these Liberal and National Party members and even the other Labor Party members who oppose it, because most of them when they understand it—even the Labor local government people—accept and support this proposal.

answer.para: The mechanism is very simple. The states will get that money on the condition that they continue at least the current payments to local government. That is, the existing general purpose grants, the existing untied road funding and the current escalation clause. So it will go up with population and CPI increases. Those guarantees were given in our election promises; they are guarantees that we have given subsequently; and they are guarantees that will stick. It is quite obvious that Senator Mackay in her enthusiasm has been concentrating on other matters rather than getting an understanding of this issue. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Will the minister inform the Senate how the government is creating opportunities for workers to improve their pay, to boost the productivity of their workplaces, to promote jobs growth and to further reduce unemployment?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —By now I think it ought to be obvious to all those who take an intelligent interest in this subject that Australia is better placed than any other country in the region. And it is no accident that that is the case. It is because we took those tough decisions. The commitment to reducing the budget deficit, which Senator Cook and others simply denied ever existed, was something that we only achieved with a great deal of political pain. But we are now reaping the rewards and, of course, so is Australia. Australian workers, as Senator Lightfoot quite rightly points out, are also significant beneficiaries.

answer.para: What has happened over the last two years to the June quarter is that the Reserve Bank index of wages and salaries has increased nearly 10 per cent after inflation, which is a fantastic performance given that we have probably the lowest inflation rates for the last 30 years. Again, that is no accident. It is very instructive to read an article in today's Financial Review by John Edwards, who is described at the bottom of the article as the `chief economist at HSBC' but who is probably better known to most of us as a former senior Labor adviser and a Keating biographer. The article states:
The secret of this economic magic is productivity growth. Australian productivity growth has been drifting up over the expansion in a way we have not seen in the last 20 years.
He goes on to explain why this is so:

The most probable specific explanation is the cumulative impact of exceptionally high business and public investment over the course of this expansion . . . While investment has been rapidly increasing, employers have also found greater freedom to reorganise work. This is the result of enterprise bargaining—
which, of course, Labor is now deadset against—
the weakness of trade unions—
in other words, their recognition that they have very little to contribute to productivity, so they butted out of the game—
and an Industrial Relations Commission which more often facilitates than blocks productivity enhancing changes in work practices.
He goes on to say that a lot of the new investment embodies new ways of using chips. So the computer revolution is a very important factor. He goes on:
the . . . greater freedom to rearrange the job is changing the way Australia works.

That is a devastating indictment of the Labor Party. These are the pessimists, these are the doomsayers, these are the people who are not interested in the sorts of reforms that got Australia to this position. Unless you are prepared to go down the path of reform and modernisation, you will go nowhere. Why is it that we still have this backward looking, rear-vision mirror view of the world? It is simply because in the Labor Party if you espouse new ideas, new reforms, you get sent to Coventry. Look at Mr Latham. He will never make a comeback, because obviously his approach is anathema.
Senator Sherry interjecting—

talk.start.para: —He will make a comeback? I am very pleased to hear it. Good luck to him. He has our support. I am delighted to know he has a few mates over there as well. While Kim Beazley is keeping the seat warm for him, there is no doubt he will have plenty of opportunities to really start delivering the goods. I am sure if you asked Mr Latham, he would tell you in spades that you have got to have more of these reforms and you have got to be committed to productivity improvements, not just union delivered handouts, not just trying to keep the lid on growth at all costs.

answer.para: Mr Beazley is the very person whose own biography has now been remaindered; it is discounted by something like 30 per cent. Guess who wrote the foreword to it? Tony Blair. Tony Blair would be too embarrassed to send him a Christmas card. He would not know what to say. He would not believe how much this bloke has gone backwards since he last gave him some advice. It is tragic. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a delegation from the United States Congress led by the Chairman of the Subcommittee on Trade of the House Ways and Means Committee, the Hon. Phillip Crane. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome you to the chamber and trust that your visit to this country will be both informative and enjoyable.
—Hear, hear!
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware of any alternative industrial relations policies, and what would be their impact if they were implemented?
—Is this really in order, Madam President?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Yes, it certainly is, Madam President, because it goes to the heart of the matter.
—Order! Senator Alston, you should not start speaking until I call you. I call Senator Alston.

—I am sorry, Madam President. This supplementary question goes to the heart of the real issue—in other words, what is it that drives productivity, what is it that makes Australia the envy of the region? It is all the sorts of things that you do not believe in anymore. You ask yourself how it was that you defied gravity—
—Order! Senator Alston, direct your remarks through the chair.

—The Labor Party ought to ask itself how it managed to defy gravity for all those years and stay in office. It was because it actually believed in something. It was committed to deregulation of the financial system. It wanted to liberalise foreign investment. It wanted to privatise. It wanted to introduce franking credits. In other words, it had its eye on the ball.

answer.para: What we see now is a Labor Party that is totally bereft of any ideas. It is not interested in delivering the goods for workers. It is simply interested in pandering to the unions. John Edwards, in quoting Mr Keating in those years when Labor was actually considering privatisation of Telstra, described Mr Beazley as pathetically weak and spineless, captured by the unions. That is what it is all about—captured by the unions. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I call Senator Carr.
—No, Madam President.
—I call Senator Murphy.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Local Government

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. Can the minister recall telling the General Assembly of Local Government on 9 November 1998 that:

question.para: Only on fee for service charges will there be any GST in the same way as it would apply to a commercial service provided by a private company.
Then in relation to applying a GST to swimming pool fees, you said:
Some people go out and say `gee whiz', some of us have got to pay a little bit more.
Minister, are you aware that the Liberal Party Director, Lynton Crosby, told local government in correspondence on 17 September 1998 that:
The non commercial activities of government will be outside the scope of the GST. That means that where a service is provided free of charge or for a nominal charge, the GST will not apply.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I must say that the question is confusing—I suspect like the senator's understanding. Perhaps I could start with the conference. I was told that your representative at the conference, and also the Democrats' representative, promised to give local government 6.5 per cent of GST takings. Is that right? Is that what you said, Senator Mackay? How can you give them 6.5 per cent of GST takings if you are opposing the GST? You are opposing the GST, yet you are giving them that. That is what I am told by some Western Australian mayors. I must say, Senator Mackay, that I did not hear your speech, thankfully, but some Western Australian mayors tell me that that is what you promised—and you too, Senator Lees. You promised them 6.5 per cent of GST takings, yet you are opposing the GST. It just does not ring true.

answer.para: Senator Murphy or Senator Carr, whichever one you are: if it is a—

talk.start.para: —Senator Macdonald, your remarks should be directed through the chair.

—Thank you, Madam President. The question from Senator Murphy quite clearly recounted what I said. What I said is correct, and it is what Lynton Crosby also said. Non-commercial activities of local government will be GST free. Rates, water, sewerage and regulatory charges, all GST free. That is quite correct. But on commercial activities where local governments compete with private enterprise, their customers—not them—will pay a GST fee, the same as customers of any private organisation.

answer.para: I use the example of a swimming pool. Customers who are now paying $2 to get into private swimming pools that are operating around Australia will pay an extra 10 per cent or 20c. So they will pay $2.20. But remember that the people who are paying that will have some $40 to $50 extra in their pockets each week as a result of the tax reform package. Out of that $40 or $50 extra each week, they could afford to pay the 20c extra on the swimming pool. If it is a swimming pool that does not charge, Senator Murphy—and perhaps there are some like that; I am not aware of any—then you will still pay 10 per cent on the entrance fee. But if the entrance fee is zero, 10 per cent of zero is zero so it will not apply. Senator Murphy, you obviously share your shadow minister's misunderstanding or complete lack of understanding of how the GST and the tax reform system works.

I invite Senator Murphy, as I invited Senator Mackay, to come around to my office and get a briefing on how the GST works. Once you understand how it works, you will find that it is a great system. It is good for Australia and it is good for your constituents. Your constituents will, generally speaking, end up with more money in their pockets.

Senator Murphy mentioned the cost of living going up. I have said that everyone will experience that and understand it. We have made no secret of it. We said that the cost of living would go up by 1.9 per cent. But we set out to make sure that no-one suffered and that if you are in the work force your tax reductions are more than 1.9 per cent. If you are on a pension or some other government payment, your payments go up by four per cent to cover the 1.9 per cent increase. It is pretty simple. It is great for all Australians. I do wish that Senator Murphy would understand it.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Obviously local government has not understood the minister. If his answers to local government are anything like the answer that he has given here, they would be about as clear as mud. The minister might like to answer this supplementary question. Will the Vos report recommendation that goods and services sold at less than 50 per cent of market price by charities be GST free, be extended to local government? Do you believe that parents of children paying extra to use their local, and usually non-profitable, swimming pool and the elderly paying extra to attend social activities at their local seniors centre will really say `Gee whiz' to every additional charge?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Most other Australians can understand the GST. During the election campaign, I went around, as did all my colleagues, to any number of organisations, including Rotary, businesses and schools—everywhere. Once it was explained—once you said, `Don't believe the Labor lies. This is how it works',—you could actually see most people go, `Gee, that is good, isn't it.' They voted for it because they understand it. They understand that it is a good system. But, obviously, it is beyond the wit of the people that the Labor Party put into the Senate. I can understand that, because I happen to know that nearly every senator opposite has never had a real job. They have only ever been union organisers or organisers of the Australian Labor Party. There are one or two teachers. Teaching is a good profession, but Senator Ray left it—they probably kicked him out. Senator Faulkner left it—they probably kicked him out. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the minister to Senator Lightfoot's outrageous attack on the judiciary in this place last night when he referred to a decision of a Federal Court justice as insane. I ask: is the Prime Minister concerned about the growing, undeniable pattern of attacks by the government on the judiciary, which this week has been fuelled by the Deputy Prime Minister, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and now Senator Lightfoot? Isn't this similar to the established pattern of attacks by the executive on the parliament through a deliberate public relations strategy to foster the false image of a hostile Senate? Has the Prime Minister given explicit approval to the obvious PR strategy to attack and undermine the judiciary, which represents a threat to the executive in general and to the coalition's born to rule mentality in particular? If not, will he act to put a stop to the repeated attacks by members of his government on the very fabric of the Westminster system?

—The public will be able to judge later this week whether there is a hostile Senate. It will have the opportunity to vote on the government's private health care rebate—a policy that was taken to the Australian people within the last few months and put to them specifically, and upon which the government was in part re-elected. So if that gets voted down against the public's wishes, reinforced by polls showing over 70 per cent public support, within a couple of months of the election, the public will then know that they have a hostile Senate. That is probably the best judge they have.

answer.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —He asked me about a hostile Senate. I am telling him the best test that he will be able to apply. He will be able to apply it within a few days.

answer.para: We on this side of the chamber do not disapprove of debate on judicial decisions. We do not see that there is anything wrong with debating a judicial outcome. We think it is quite a healthy thing within a democracy such as ours. But in doing so, we seek not to attack judges personally or to attack the system. In fact, we on this side of the chamber seek to support the system, because judicial independence and a strong judicial system is critical to the health of our democracy. Senator Bartlett should see that distinction. Certainly on this side of the chamber, we think that to quarrel about a particular judicial judgment—to argue about the law or the application of the facts or whatever—is quite healthy. We do not see any reason to apologise for that.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that interesting answer to a small section of my question. I notice, as Minister Vanstone helpfully and very eloquently informed me yesterday in question time, that everyone has a right to criticise in a democracy. That is why the Democrats are criticising the executive's ongoing and apparently coordinated campaign to undermine the legitimacy of the parliament and the judiciary. Wouldn't the minister agree that the Prime Minister has a special responsibility to ensure that the judiciary is not exposed to a pattern of what looks, walks and quacks like a coordinated campaign to undermine its public reputation by coalition members?

—Certainly the Prime Minister accepts his responsibility, as we all do, to uphold the integrity of the judicial system. As I just said to the honourable senator, it is a cornerstone of our democracy. We do not shy away from that at all. But, on the other hand, we will not condemn somebody who criticises a particular judgment or who argues about or debates a particular judgment. We regard that as a sign of the totally healthy state of our democracy as well.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Can the minister confirm that the proposed Western Sydney orbital will cut the transit time for vehicles, such as big trucks, travelling from the Hume Highway south of Sydney to the Pacific Highway in the north by over one hour? Can the minister further confirm that the Western Sydney orbital will greatly improve Western Sydney's transport system, reducing traffic on suburban streets and improving access to Sydney for people living in the central west of New South Wales? Can the minister explain to the Senate why his government has failed to match the commitments given by the Australian Labor Party both in government and in opposition to provide significant Commonwealth funding for its development?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —What I can tell the senator is that this government has made a special effort to look after roads in Australia. In fact, we have reintroduced some programs that your party got rid of, like the black spots program—a great program. Your party introduced it when you were in government and then, inexplicably, you stopped it. We have recommenced that; we have recommitted funds to it; and those funds will be well used for roads right around Australia.

answer.para: I recently had the honour of representing Mr Anderson at the opening of the extension of the F3 freeway at Newcastle, and I know Senator Tierney did a lot towards that particular extension by constantly badgering many governments over a long period of time. So we in fact have made a real commitment to roads and we will continue that commitment.

I understand Senator Hutchins is concerned about roads. He was, as I had occasion to mention last week, a member of the Transport Workers Union. He had some serious position in that, I assume, but never drove a truck. I guess that is what it is all about. It is typical of the Labor Party that it is pretty good to come in here and play games, pretty good to organise strikes and pretty good to get involved in the waterfront, but when it comes down to real jobs and when it comes down to really understanding what roads are all about—

talk.start.para: —Senator Macdonald, I do draw your attention to the question.
—Thank you, Madam President. The point of order I was going to take is that it would be pretty good if the minister had a crack at answering the question about the Western Sydney orbital.
—I can understand Senator Faulkner looking after Senator Hutchins because it was Senator Hutchins who got enough votes in the Senate election to bring Senator Faulkner in.
—And I thanked him for it.
—You thanked him for it? I didn't think you talked to the right wing of your party.
—Senator Macdonald!
—I have been distracted, Madam President, and I apologise for that. We do have, in fact, a great commitment to roads, as a government that is concerned about—
—What about Senator Macdonald? That is who we did in—your namesake. Our team seemed to go a hell of a lot better than yours.
—Order! There is far too much noise for me to hear what Senator Macdonald is saying.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. This is hopeless. He was quick to his feet when he thought he had a point of order, but the interjections by which the minister is not able to answer the question are equally disorderly and he ought to stay in his seat.

—Madam President, on the point of order: I suggest you direct the minister to answer the question that was directed to him about the Western Sydney orbital. He has not even tried to answer a serious question that was asked by Senator Hutchins. We are willing to accept all the credit for defeating Senator Sandy Macdonald in New South Wales, but get him to answer the question!

—Senator Faulkner, you are grossly in breach of the standing orders and you were shouting during the answer to the question. There are other senators interjecting as well and that is also disorderly. Senator Macdonald, I draw your attention to the question that you were asked and remind you to address your remarks to the chair.

—The amount of money that this government has spent on roads in New South Wales is quite dramatic—unlike, I have to say, the current New South Wales government. Apparently every time an election comes up the Labor government in New South Wales promises a road somewhere. It never eventuates. It is typical of Labor Party actions on that.

answer.para: I have a list, which I can provide at some later date to honourable senators, of the amount of money that this government has spent on roads in New South Wales—quite a dramatic list of money that has been spent because we understand how important roads are, and we will continue to fund them.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I do not recall, in any of that answer, that Senator Macdonald referred to the importance of the Western Sydney orbital to people in Western Sydney, so I will ask this as a supplementary: isn't the government's failure to build the Western Sydney orbital symptomatic of the wider problem of the Howard government's cutting of road funding—cuts which have seen over $600 million cut from the Labor government's forward estimates for the national highway? Furthermore, isn't it true that roads in marginal Liberal seats have been preferred over major projects, such as the Western Sydney orbital, which would bring massive benefits to people who live both in regional New South Wales and Western Sydney?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The New South Wales government seems to be pretty good at giving Senator Hutchins questions to ask, but pretty poor on actually funding roads themselves.
—You're a liar.

—Someone mentioned about me being a liar. Let me put the lie to the questioner. In fact, this government has increased road funding from $1.597 billion in 1995-96 to $1.612 billion. That is a pretty good increase from this government. We have increased federal funding to $750 million to rebuild the Pacific Highway from Hexham to the Queensland border. Do you know where Hexham is? It is in your state, Senator.

answer.para: We have spent $450 million on roads of national importance. We have spent $149 million on road safety black spot funding. We have provided an enormous amount of money—$61 million for the Raymond Terrace bypass, $130 million for the Bulahdelah to Coolongolook deviation, and so the list goes on. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question goes to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, and it is about the Tarkine wilderness in north-west Tasmania. I ask the minister: is a third of this wilderness, namely, the Arthur-Pieman conservation area, to be protected as such under the Regional Forest Agreement signed by the Prime Minister last year? Is the state government of Tasmania currently negotiating to downgrade that 101 hectares of magnificent wild country from conservation area status to regional reserve status at the behest of the mining industry—along with some 46 other areas, including every protected beach area in Tasmania? Can the minister say whether the RFA is renegotiable, or is there some mechanism by which the state government could unilaterally downgrade these reserves? If not, will the minister give an assurance that no such reclassification will take place?

—As I understand it, Senator Brown is expressing concern at the action of the Tasmanian Labor government. I would have thought he is probably much closer to Labor in Tasmania than I am. But, no, they cannot unilaterally change the RFA. The RFA negotiated between the coalition government here in Canberra and the then predominantly Liberal government in Tasmania achieved excellent outcomes. It created 396,000 hec tares of new reserves, including 29 new areas of national park and state reserves, which increased the conservation reserve system by 17 per cent, and I presume that Senator Brown is applauding that, by inference, in his question.

answer.para: On the other hand, although he was not as interested, it also created 550 jobs in plantations, and intensive forest management and infrastructure development through the Commonwealth's $110 million contribution to the RFA outcome. I remind the Senate that the package included $70 million for a hardwood plantation, intensive forest management and an industry development program. It also included $10 million for infrastructure, including tourism facilities, and $30 million for the protection of private land.

It was a good all-round outcome: good for conservation and good for jobs. I find it interesting that Senator Brown now comes in here and complains that the Tasmanian Labor government might be trying to undermine the conservation outcomes of that negotiated agreement. They cannot do it unilaterally, that is true. But, in criticising the Tasmanian Labor government, perhaps Senator Brown might also reflect upon the New South Wales Labor government. The basis for this is that in Tasmania we were able to protect 88 per cent of forest ecosystems under the JANIS criteria.

The unilateral decision of the New South Wales Labor government to abandon the negotiation with the Commonwealth government means that they have protected just 36 per cent—36 per cent against the Liberal's 88 per cent. In relation to old growth, what we did in Tasmania was protect 83 per cent. What Mr Carr is prepared to protect is only 18 per cent. If ever there were a demonstration that it is the coalition and Liberal governments in the states that are really interested in conservation reserves and conservation values, I would have suggested those figures are the proof of that fact. If Senator Brown sought to use his influence on Labor governments around Australia, he would better achieve the conservation outcomes which he claims to represent.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would agree with the minister that the Labor government in Tasmania is a disgrace to the word environment when it comes to government. But I asked the minister to further clarify his assurance that there is no way that the RFA can be used to downgrade the status of conservation areas. Can he give a commitment that there will be no mining within the Arthur-Pieman conservation area and no damage to forest, through mining or any other mechanism, in this area that he has so eloquently said is his intention to protect under the regional forest agreement? Or is it true that, despite having the name conservation area applied to it, he plans to allow mining to take place in this area which includes magnificent Aboriginal sites, one of which was damaged—in fact, destroyed and stolen—in a recent raid on the area by thieves so far unknown.
—Not by the mining industry, though?
—We don't know.

—As Senator Brown would know, the regional forest agreement sets out various levels of conservation reserves and uses that are permitted in those reserves that are compatible with the conservation values. They are included within the RFA which is being legislated upon in Tasmania at the moment. The Tasmanian government is obliged to maintain the categorisations that are included within the RFA. It is a simple is that.

—My question without notice is to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, do you recall stating in the Senate recently that the Howard government had created some 55,000 extra vocational education and training places last year, and that this had been done through efficiencies? Is the minister aware that two Victorian TAFEs are close to insolvency because of government cuts, and that these two institutions are located in Melbourne's northern suburbs, an area with an extraordinarily high level of youth unemployment? I draw to the minister's attention that the Kangan-Batman TAFE, even after severe budgetary restraints, will finish 1998 with a cash balance covering less than five operating days. Also, the 1999 budget of the Northern College of TAFE contains a funding cut of $1.8 million, which, as the chief executive officer has stated, means that the college can no longer continue to operate in the long-term in its current form. Minister, will you now concede that the government's policy of growth through efficiencies has resulted in a severe funding crisis for many of the nation's TAFEs?

—The start of Senator Carr's question is wrong because I never said that the Howard government had created 55,000 new positions. I said that we had done so with the cooperation of the states through growth through efficiencies. Senator Carr ought to remember that that was brought about by the ANTA agreement, which he quizzed me on to a great extent in this very chamber. That was about working with the states and territories in achieving growth through efficiencies. That could only be done by a cooperative effort with the states and territories. Whilst the 55,000 is correct, it was done by that concerted effort. As to the ramifications of that in each state, Senator Carr is perhaps best off asking the relevant ministers. The state of Victoria has a very good vocational education training system. Preliminary NCVER data from June 1998 shows that there have been at least 111,000 new apprenticeship commencements and recommencements in the 1997-98 financial year. That is something the Howard government does take credit for.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are you aware that the Victorian minister for vocational education and training, Mr Honeywood, has attributed the shortfalls in funding to the Commonwealth government's cutback under the ANTA agreement? Will you now acknowledge, with the mounting evidence that TAFE is facing a crisis in this country and given that this government is seeking to establish 500,000 additional places within five years with no additional moneys from the Common wealth, that such cuts cannot be imposed without serious cuts to the quality of the service provision across Australia's 84 TAFEs?

—I remind Senator Carr that across this county there are in excess of 186,000 people in training at this moment. That is a record figure. That displays only a system which is working. That shows that the government policies are on track. I say once again that the states and territories signed up to the ANTA agreement. They were happy with that agreement. Senator Carr, you will recall that you tried to say at the time that this was an agreement that would not work. It has resulted in a record number of people in training. It has resulted in 55,000 places. That is where we are going with vocational education and training in this country; we are going towards record levels of people in training.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Customs. Yesterday, Customs and the Australian Federal Police seized the largest haul of cocaine in Australian history. This follows a number of other record seizures of illicit drugs, for example, heroin and amphetamines.
—Senators on my left are making it hard for me to hear the question.
—He is too busy exhaling, Madam President. My question to the minister is: how has the government's balanced approach through the Tough on Drugs strategy assisted in these seizures?

—I thank Senator O'Chee for the question. This government has a three-pronged approach to drugs, which is well understood by anybody who is interested in government policy: law enforcement, harm minimisation and education. My role focuses on the law enforcement aspect with Ministers Wooldridge and Kemp focusing on the harm minimisation and education. Successful law enforcement strategies help to prevent the flood of drugs into our community. Some, sadly, seek to denigrate any focus on law enforcement, to diminish its achievement and its successes, by doing one of two things. They choose, whenever there is a law enforcement success, to highlight what we all agree with—that is, that law enforcement alone is not enough; everyone agrees with that. We recognise that we need harm minimisation strategies and we recognise that we need education programs as well.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Just a minute, Senator. Sledging is disorderly.

—We are funding all three. But the need for those other two programs should never be allowed to darken the light over law enforcement and the achievement it makes. Some, even more sadly, do not acknowledge the role of all three and just say there is far too much emphasis on law enforcement.

answer.para: The Australian Customs Service and the Federal Police yesterday made the largest cocaine seizure in Australia's history. We had 13 years of Labor, but we have had the largest cocaine seizure in Australia's history and that follows the largest heroin seizure in Australia's history and the largest seizure of amphetamines in Australia's history.

Madam President, you may remember—perhaps Senator Stott Despoja does not—the words of Carole Bayer Sager's song: `It looks as though we are doing something right'. It really does look as though we are doing something right. We would have hoped to have all-party support for success in the law enforcement area in relation to drugs. This is another devastating blow against major international drug syndicates. We make no apology for the fact that the law enforcement arm of Tough on Drugs is aimed quite specifically at smashing the transnational organised crime groups that would flood Australia with illicit drugs if left unchecked. As I said, we had hoped for all-party support on that matter.

We do not think there can be too great an emphasis on the law enforcement arm of that three-part strategy. This seizure represents a street value of over $50 million, one million hits of a dangerous and addictive drug taken off the streets. It follows a seizure in October of over 400 kilos of heroin. Since July of this year, the Federal Police have seized over 500 kilos of heroin. We are working effectively to break up major syndicates and to make it much more likely that street level impacts will emerge.

Politicians as role models in Australia do need to send a clear message to young Australians condemning illicit drug use and supporting efforts to keep drugs out of Australia. You are not a cool banana if you indulge in amphetamines. You are not a cool banana if you try heroin or cocaine. That is the proper, responsible message that should go to young Australians. Law enforcement alone is not enough; we need education and we need harm minimisation. This government will never go soft on drugs. We will never say, `Bring it all in and we will rely on the good sense of young Australians to say no,' because that is a very stupid policy to follow, and we will never endorse it.

talk.start.para: —If I can recover from the cool banana analogy, I want to ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care a question. Will the minister give the guarantee that Dr Wooldridge was unwilling to give yesterday that, in return for their $1.5 billion bonus, the private health insurance funds would at least be required to comply with all of the consumer protection provisions in Commonwealth law?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Evans for the question because it brings up the very important point of the rebate that the government is putting forward to the Senate to allow the government to give people an incentive to either retain their private health insurance or attract them to private health insurance. I can assure Senator Evans that at all times we will ensure that the law is followed. I have no doubt that Dr Wooldridge would support me in that.

answer.para: The question before us put by Senator Evans is to the legality or otherwise of what we are proposing. There is no question about that. I do not understand the insanity of the opposition to what we are proposing in that the alternative is a completely publicised health system, which is, I suppose, ideologically pure for the Labor Party to pursue. Over the 13 years of their government, they deliberately tried to destroy the private health system of this country. I suppose they are being ideologically pure in that because the alternative to what we are doing is to overload the public hospital system. They do not seem to realise that. I am sorry, Senator, that I have to lecture you again on this because you obviously do not understand it.

talk.start.para: —Any lecture should be through the chair.

—My apologies, Madam President, but I keep getting congratulated by the other side on the lectures that I give them on the health system of this country because they just do not understand it. We are trying to say to the mums and dads of this country that, if you insure yourself, we will give you a rebate on that insurance of up to $750. We are saying, `Please take out private health insurance to take the pressure off the public hospital system.' It is as simple as that.

answer.para: We want to maintain that balance between the public and the private hospital systems of this country, and we can only do it if people take out private health insurance. Those on the other side do not seem to realise that those people are already paying the Medicare levy, if they have a taxable income. They are already paying that. In addition, we are trying to give them an incentive to take out private health insurance. It is fairly simple. It will achieve a successful result.

It has been estimated conservatively by us that it will bring in about another three per cent, or half a million people. It has been estimated by others that it will bring in a much greater number. So the opposition and the Democrats should get on with agreeing with our legislation so that we can get an equitable system once again in this country.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question, and I will read the Hansard to try to interpret what the minister actually said then. Does the minister acknowledge that the funds have not been complying with consumer protection requirements? Is he aware that the Private Health Insurance Ombudsman has slated the health funds for failing to use plain English in policy documentation, changing the rules governing members' entitlements without making these publicly available, failing to give benefit protection to consumers who pay premiums in advance and misapplying the test of `pre-existing conditions' to deny consumers coverage? What action does the government propose to take to enforce the law?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Evans for the question. The opposition leader actually said that the funds ripped their members off. That is what their leader said. It is obviously a gross exaggeration.

answer.para: The number of complaints to the Private Health Insurance Ombudsman has risen over the last 12 months but, to put this in context, the Ombudsman received fewer than 2,000 complaints while health funds processed more than 30 million claims in that year. For 30 million claims, they got 2,000 complaints. I think that is an outstanding result, but the opposition leader has gone right over the top and said that they are ripping off their members. Compared to the previous year, it is likely to reflect an increase in public awareness of the Private Health Insurance Ombudsman. Even Senator Evans should be aware of that. He complains about putting things in plain English. I suggest he put his questions in plain English too while he is about it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —On Thursday, 3 December, Senator Woodley asked me a question relating to airport privatisation. I undertook to obtain further information from the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Mr Anderson has provided me with a detailed response, and I seek leave for that document to be incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

The major (core regulated) airports except Sydney are subject to a CPI-X price cap where X is a different percentage for each airport. In effect the airport operators must reduce real prices for five years on a specific set of aeronautical services. The services were formally declared by the Treasurer under the Prices Surveillance Act.

Price increases must be notified to the ACCC, and the ACCC will use this information plus the financial statements of airport lessees, to assess compliance with the price cap. In addition to the price cap on aeronautical services, a set of aeronautical related services are price monitored by the ACCC.
There seem to be three main areas where BARA is concerned

The CTFR function is currently required by Air Navigation Regulations to be performed at the highest categorised airports in Australia. In essence it is a guaranteed presence of an empowered force to provide a deterrence against, and an initial response to, an act of terrorism Previously the Australian Protective Service (APS) had a virtual monopoly on providing the CTFR function, but the government has recently allowed airport operators to seek expressions of interest from the Australian Federal Police and relevant State/Territory police, as well as the APS, should they wish.

BARA is concerned at having a "third party" role in this matter ie. paying for a function, through airport operator charges, which reflects the cost of meeting a Government mandated requirement on airport operators. However the government is taking airline views into account, along with other interested parties, in examining the CTFR function.

Following privatisation, costs have been fully devolved to each airport. As a result there have been significant increases in CTFR costs, particularly at airports with relatively few international flights. The Government is completing a review of the need for a CTFR requirement at Townsville, Hobart and Alice Springs, in the light of the low risk at each airport. The Government has a strong interest in achieving more efficient CTFR arrangements and will consider any reasonable proposals which could contribute to the lowering of costs. However this will not be at the risk of compromising a proper CTFR regulatory response in the event of an incident at our biggest international airports.

As part of the sale agreements the privatised airports committed themselves to almost $700 million in investment, although this amount includes some items such as maintenance that are not new investment.
There is no direct relationship between the Development Commitments and the prices oversight regime.

It as largely a matter for the airlines and the airports to negotiate over airport lessees' proposals for new capital expenditure and the costs associated with such proposals. The outcome of these discussions would then need to be put to the ACCC for its agreement.

Prior to privatisation, the Federal Airports Corporation negotiated contracts with the fuel companies for leases over refuelling facilities at most Federal airports that included provision for throughput levies on fuel. Some airport lessees are now seeking to implement these levies however the airlines have complained to the ACCC that implementation of the levies is an abuse of market power by the airports. The airlines argue that the fuel throughput levy will significantly reduce the benefits from the CPI-X cap at those airports where it is implemented.

Under the post-privatisation prices oversight regime, refuelling facilities are aeronautical related services (ie outside the CPI-X price cap) monitored by the ACCC. It was the Government's intention in structuring the prices oversight regime as it did that the ACCC would oversight implementation of the regime. The ACCC sought and received submissions on the fuel throughput levy earlier in the year and the issue is currently under consideration.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Local Government

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government (Senator Ian Macdonald) to a question without notice asked today relating to local government and the Government's goods and services tax.

I would like to commence by clarifying what we are saying here. We are saying that local government does not understand the GST, local government does not agree with handing funding over to the states. It is not just the Labor Party saying this. This is not just about misinformation by the Labor Party.

What we have and what we saw with the Local Government Association of Queensland is a multi-partisan view with regard to this. It is just not good enough for the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government to come in here and continue what I regard as a fairly patronising attitude and slag off local governments. By the time Senator Macdonald has finished, he will have bagged just about every local council in Australia. When I did a Hansard search in relation to Senator Macdonald, that is pretty much what I found—not much on local government policy whatsoever.

Local government are very annoyed about their exclusion from the process. They are very annoyed about the fact that they were actually cut out of it. They are very annoyed that the coalition will not come clean as to what mechanism will be used in terms of guaranteeing funding from the Commonwealth to local governments. As far as they are concerned, money will be handed over to the states and the states will do what they wish. The only hint we have—and that is why I was pressing Senator Macdonald—is what mechanism will be used. We have a hint that it might be a memorandum of understanding. Our response to that is that it is not good enough. The response of local government to that is also that it is not good enough.

Local government do not understand the GST. It is simply misleading for the minister to come in here and assert they do. As I said in the Senate the other day, his own council of the Burdekin Shire have produced documentation which says that 50 per cent of the services they provide are in the grey area—they are unclear as to whether the GST is applicable or not. Logan council, also in his home state, have produced documentation. As far as that council are concerned, they are unclear as to whether a GST is applicable to 30 per cent of the services they provide.

This is why the Queensland Local Government Association have decided to launch Operation Rethink. I will quote exactly what Operation Rethink is. Tom Pyne, who I think is a terrific person—and I acknowledge that Senator Macdonald said that as well—is also a card-carrying member of the Labor Party. That is fine. There were plenty of card-carrying members of the National Party and the Liberal Party at the meeting I attended. This article states:
The Local Government Association has launched Operation Rethink in an attempt to curb the handover of local government funding to the states.
The LGA has launched the campaign to try to change some aspects of the Coalition's proposed taxation and intergovernmental financial arrangements that it sees as detrimental to local government.
How much clearer can you get? Executive director of the Queensland Local Government Association, Greg Hallam, was quoted as saying:

We're saying to councils, give consideration to requesting your local federal Coalition member or Senator to attend one of your council meetings in February, or March, and explain to the council and more importantly the community why this had to happen.
Why local government couldn't get the same share as the states, and what safety guarantees are there beyond the three year transitional period.

That is from the Queensland Local Government Association. We have already expressed very strongly the view that was provided by the Australian Local Government Association, and I have had occasion now to meet with a number of councils and local government associations, and the message is the same: they do not agree with the transfer of funding over to the states, they are completely in the dark as to what mechanism is going to be used and, if it is a memorandum of understanding, that is not good enough.

I note that in the tax bills the only mention of funding between the federal government and the states was in the preamble, which said that there was a Premiers Conference and certain undertakings were given. There is nothing in there about local government except to say that every single act where the fiscal situation is articulated will be repealed. What does that mean? We are here asking questions and local government also want to ask questions. I think it about time the government, instead of asserting that everything is okay and everybody understands it, actually came clean and gave people some answers.

talk.start.para: —Here we are again one week later and we have the same old story, the same old attack, the same old Labor lies and the same old Labor Party scare tactics which have been going on for the last six years. I have been involved in local government in one way or another for most of my life. I know how local government is funded and I also know that, in recent times, local government has become very efficient by contracting out and privatising a lot of its operations.

speech.para: Senator Ian Macdonald, as a former councillor, is also very well aware of how local government operates. He came in here today and answered the same questions about local government that he was asked last week. One has to ask what the Labor Party are on about. We have sat here through this whole session and all we have heard from the Labor Party are these negative attacks on the GST. All through the election campaign all we ever heard was negative attacks on the GST. When are they ever going to come up with something positive, something for the good of Australia?

We have come forward with a tax reform plan which includes a GST, and it is going to be good for all Australia, including local government. The Australian Labor Party—Senator Mackay and the rest of it—have used misleading tactics. I have heard it all. I have heard through my local government contacts that there is going to be a GST on rates. That was a lie—wrong; absolutely wrong. I have heard that all the regulatory charges are going to have a GST on them. That is wrong. One of the doozies that was put around by the Labor Party was that there was even going to be a tax on parking fines. That was wrong.

talk.start.para: —Who put that around?

—You people put it around, like you put all the scare tactics around about everything about the GST. You know as well as I do, Senator O'Brien, that this country needs a very big shake-up as far as taxes are concerned. I know as a former local government councillor that one of the biggest problems we ever had was getting a decent share of money from Canberra. At least under a GST—as you know, Madam Deputy President, and as they know over there—money will be coming through on a regular basis. The Commonwealth government will get none of it. We have guaranteed that all the GST funding will go to the states and through the states to local government.

speech.para: Another Labor lie that has been peddled around local government is that the Commonwealth Grants Commission will still be kept to make sure that local government gets a fair share of government funding. Local government representatives campaigned long and hard before and during the election campaign in support of tax reform. They know as well as we that tax reform is essential to all Australia, including local government. They put a very persuasive case to the government with respect to the exclusion of rates, water and sewerage charges. You may remember that, during the Fightback campaign, there was some doubt about whether rates and services under local government were going to be exempt from a GST. This time there is an ironclad guarantee that there will be no GST on them.

talk.start.para: —Congratulations to you, because you probably helped the lobbying.

—Thank you for that comment, Senator Mackay. The fact of the matter is that local government will be better off under these new tax reform packages. One of the big problems that local government has always had—and I suppose always will have, to a certain extent—is a guarantee of funding. Local governments are the grassroots of government. They are the ones who deal on a day-to-day basis with the man in the street who, at the end of the day, is really only concerned about whether his potholes have been filled up and whether his sewerage works, et cetera.

speech.para: But, as I said, in recent times local government has become very efficient. It contracts out a lot of its services. It does not have the huge overheads that it used to have. I am particularly pleased to see that, in our state of Tasmania—even though the previous state government was defeated I believe basically over local government reform—business people and local people alike are making moves to amalgamate certain local government areas and to become more efficient.

What we have heard from the Labor Party in recent times about tax reform has been like a cracked record. I cannot believe that, one week later, after all that is happening around Australia—all the good things and all the bad things—we get the same old questions to the same minister from the same people. They must have run out of ideas over there. Can't you come up with something a little different or something that is going to benefit this country? Honest to goodness, I cannot believe it! (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to take note of the non-answers from Senator Ian Macdonald with regard to GST and local government. Senator Macdonald is running a very close second to poor old Senator Kemp, who is the chief waffler on the government side with regard to non-answers and non-performance. That is really saying something for Senator Macdonald. Last week Senator Macdonald, in answer to a question from Senator Mackay with regard to how the GST will apply to local government, said:

speech.para: . . . local government, once the truth is explained to them—
which obviously he has not been able to do—
are very happy about the GST. They now understand that they do not pay GST at all.
That is very interesting, because Senator Macdonald said something different from that in another statement and that was contradicted by Lynton Crosby, who said something different again.

If local government is so au fait with what was going on and how the GST would apply, why are they writing to all senators, including all government senators and Senator Macdonald to boot? Why are they seeking to brief us? Why is the President of the ALGA saying things like, `I am seeking urgent and strong action from councils in support of this position, including representation to local members of parliament.'? Because they do not know how the GST will apply to them. They do not know what services it will apply to and what services it will not apply to, as was pointed out with regard to where nominal fees are paid for local government services, such as swimming pools, community halls, et cetera. Will the GST apply or won't it? Senator Macdonald does not know. He went on to say last week:
. . . we will be working through in the next few months and clarifying exactly what is subject to a GST. It is where it is commercial and where commercial operators provide it.

That is about as clear as mud. What does that mean? Under the compulsory competitive tendering processes, what will be the case with regard to the GST where a council has privatised a service? Will the GST apply to services such as part rubbish collection in Victoria, for instance? I would suspect that it would. It would have to. If a private company provides a service to local government which will not be subject to a GST, what is the case when that private company provides other services in the private sector which will be subject to a GST? How does that work? How would a company not be able to take advantage of a local government contract and also provide other services to the private sector? How does the government deal with circumstances such as that? I would suggest they cannot. I would suggest the GST will apply. It is about time the government was up-front and honest with people, including local government, and told them exactly what the GST will apply to.

More importantly, in so far as local government services are concerned, in the future there will be changes of government and decisions have to be made with regard to maintaining the funding levels for local government and the provision of local government services. Local governments are equally concerned about that. They are equally concerned that there will be no equity. They already know that this government has reneged on promises that were made some time ago with regard to the maintenance of funding for local government—the money they need to provide services.

talk.start.para: —Fifteen million dollars.

—Yes, $15 million, as Senator Mackay says. How do you maintain funding? Senator Macdonald says, `Oh, well, through the CPI and population increases.' That is interesting for rural and regional Australia. For most areas you can scrub population increase, because all the services that the government has been responsible for removing has led to a population decline. How do you answer that? Senator Macdonald, hazy as he is for most of the time and in a fog for the rest of the time—and we may well know how that fog is inflicted upon him—ought to clarify the issues for local government. He ought to come in here and give some answers that are clearly and easily understood. He has not done so in the past. (Time expired)

—It is interesting to hear the attempts day by day of Labor trying to bring down the tax reform proposals of the government. We are seeing rather pathetic tactics here today to pick up the comments of a couple of well-identified Labor Party stalwarts, which were identified by Senator Macdonald. That is not to say that those people cannot make a contribution, but we should not pretend in this chamber that the people making comments on behalf of local government are anything other than Labor Party stalwarts.

speech.para: As I said, they have a contribution to make. As Labor Party stalwarts, they would abide by Labor Party's centralist policies. The Labor Party is very keen to ensure that control of local government is kept in the hands of Canberra. This government has created an historic change to federal-state and federal-local government financial relations. Labor squeal and squawk because a government has come to Canberra that has not only grasped the nettle, as it was described at the press club by the speaker there on 5 June 1985, grasped the tax reform nettle, but also grasped the nettle of federal-state financial relations.

We have said that we will ensure that funding decisions are decentralised. We have all these centralists opposite who would prefer to keep control of every purse string and every economic lever here in the national capital and away from the capitals of our great states and regions. They do not trust people in Perth, or in Brisbane, or in Melbourne, or in Sydney or in the great regional centres to make decisions for themselves. They do not trust them. They have to control them by a central piece of legislation, a bureaucrat and a handful of politicians sitting here in Canberra. This great decision, which has been made by a forward looking government that is interested in creating historic change, will have been delivered if it gets through this Senate. We encourage honourable senators to look at it closely.

We also encourage members of the Local Government Association who are not Labor Party stalwarts to read about the reforms, to ask questions about the reforms—as many have done of me. When I speak to the local government people—as my friend and colleague Senator Ian Macdonald, the minister, does—the people walk away, saying, `That's fantastic. This is a good idea. It's great.' They even say, `Gee whiz, this is a great reform.'

talk.start.para: —Senator Mackay, they tell me what they think of you and your appearance before them as well, but I would not say that in the Senate because it would be unparliamentary. I advise these local government people not to listen to what Senator Mackay and others say about the tax reform package, because they are opposed to it. That is unlike Mr Keating who, as Prime Minister, in his historic speech on 5 June 1985 at the Press Club—he might have had Senator Mackay in mind—said:

speech.para: For too long the politically unpalatable decisions have been put off in this country because our politicians have not had the strength of purpose to tackle the hard issues.

When it has come to the crunch, short-term political interests have always come first. But I think it is fair to say that, at least to some extent the community as a whole has been prepared to let its politicians get away with that attitude.

Senator Mackay is one of those politicians. They would rather score the short-term point. They do not want tax reform. They probably know in their own hearts that Australia needs it. But they failed. Mr Keating failed because of the union domination of the Labor Party in 1985. But this government is going to do it. It is going to be better for local government. It will reduce the costs of local government. They will be able to provide better services for their constituents. It will reduce their costs. And it is reform that is good for Australia. I advise people in local government, `Don't listen to Mr Beazley who tells you that the price of a used car is going to go up, when we know it is going to come down by $3,000. Don't listen to them when they say that the price of going to a swimming pool is going to go up, or when Senator Mackay says that it is not going to help local government funding. They will mislead you.' They are not politicians of the future. They are politicians of the past. They want to vote for a 1930s tax system when we should look forward to a tax system for the new millennium. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The minister would have us believe today that the light has been switched on for local government associations around the country just because he has gone out and explained to them the impact of the GST. If that is so, why aren't we being flooded with press releases and letters from local government associations telling us that that is the case, telling us that we are on the wrong track? That is not the case. Time and again we are getting press releases seeking to have us make representations on their behalf.

speech.para: One of the things that local government said back on 22 October was that there must be a guarantee that local government will not be excluded from the GST negotiations, especially those related to intergovernment financial relations. Why was it then that this government failed to include local government in their terms of reference for the Vos report? Why was it then that local government was not included in detail when it came to next year's Senate inquiries? Why is it that, time and again, local government has been screaming out to be consulted about this, yet it is continually being ignored by this government?

We have heard people on the other side of the chamber, particularly the minister, say that the GST is going to be good for local government and that local government will be better off. The minister's claims that the GST is going to be good for local government have not come to fruition. We assume that rates and regulatory matters will possibly be GST free, but I do not think the government has ever addressed the issues that have been raised by the Australian Local Government Association.

It was interesting today to hear an attack made which suggested that a Queensland lord mayor was a life member of the ALP. In the Northern Territory we have probably got many local government members who belong to either political party. But if that is going to be the basis on which you attack their right to make a comment, then you have clearly got the message wrong. They are popularly elected members of their councils and they have a right, despite their political affiliations, to represent their local government councils on this issue.

Time and again local government associations have raised the issue of the dramatic change to funding that this package is going to bring. The funding will now be going straight to the states or territories to hand out. There will be a change in the way the grants will be administered.
